text: Who brought David the news of Saul's death?
verseText: And the young man who told him said, 'By chance I happened to be on Mount Gilboa, and there was Saul leaning on his spear... He said to me, 'Stand beside me and kill me...' So I stood beside him and killed him... Then I took the crown that was on his head and the armlet that was on his arm, and I have brought them here to my lord.' (ESV)

text: What city was David first anointed king over Judah?
verseText: And the men of Judah came, and there they anointed David king over the house of Judah. (ESV)

text: Who was Saul's son who was made king over Israel by Abner?
verseText: But Abner the son of Ner, commander of Saul's army, took Ish-bosheth the son of Saul and brought him over to Mahanaim, and he made him king over Gilead and the Ashurites and Jezreel and Ephraim and Benjamin and all Israel. (ESV)

text: Who killed Abner, Saul's general?
verseText: And when Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside into the midst of the gate to speak with him privately, and there he struck him in the stomach, so that he died, for the blood of Asahel his brother. (ESV)

text: Who murdered Ish-bosheth?
verseText: Now the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, set out... They came into the house as he lay on his bed in his bedroom, and they struck him and put him to death and beheaded him. They took his head and went by the way of the Arabah all night. (ESV)

text: How old was David when he became king over all Israel?
verseText: David was thirty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years. (ESV)

text: What city did David capture from the Jebusites and make his capital?
verseText: And the king and his men went to Jerusalem against the Jebusites... Nevertheless, David took the stronghold of Zion, that is, the city of David. (ESV)

text: What object did David bring into Jerusalem with great celebration?
verseText: So David went and brought up the ark of God from the house of Obed-edom to the city of David with rejoicing... So David and all the house of Israel brought up the ark of the LORD with shouting and with the sound of the horn. (ESV)

text: Who died because he touched the Ark of the Covenant incorrectly?
verseText: And when they came to the threshing floor of Nacon, Uzzah put out his hand to the ark of God and took hold of it, for the oxen stumbled. And the anger of the LORD was kindled against Uzzah, and God struck him down there because of his error, and he died there beside the ark of God. (ESV)

text: Which wife of David despised him for dancing before the Lord?
verseText: As the ark of the LORD came into the city of David, Michal the daughter of Saul looked out of the window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the LORD, and she despised him in her heart... And Michal the daughter of Saul came out to meet David and said, 'How the king of Israel honored himself today...!' (ESV)

text: What did David want to build for God, which God forbade him from building?
verseText: the king said to Nathan the prophet, 'See now, I dwell in a house of cedar, but the ark of God dwells in a tent.'... 'Go and tell my servant David, 'Thus says the LORD: Would you build me a house to dwell in?'... He shall build a house for my name...' (ESV) [God says Solomon will build it]

text: Who was Jonathan's son whom David showed kindness to for Jonathan's sake?
verseText: And Mephibosheth the son of Jonathan, son of Saul, came to David... And David said to him, 'Do not fear, for I will show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan, and I will restore to you all the land of Saul your father, and you shall eat at my table always.' (ESV)

text: What physical disability did Mephibosheth have?
verseText: Jonathan, the son of Saul, had a son who was crippled in his feet... he fell and became lame. His name was Mephibosheth. (4:4) So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, for he ate always at the king's table. Now he was lame in both his feet. (9:13) (ESV)

text: Who was the woman David saw bathing from his rooftop?
verseText: It happened, late one afternoon, when David arose from his couch and was walking on the roof of the king's house, that he saw from the roof a woman bathing; and the woman was very beautiful. (ESV)

text: Who was Bathsheba's husband?
verseText: And David sent and inquired about the woman. And one said, 'Is not this Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?' (ESV)

text: How did David arrange for Uriah's death?
options: Ordered Joab to place him in the front line of battle and withdraw
verseText: In the letter he wrote, 'Set Uriah in the forefront of the hardest fighting, and then draw back from him, that he may be struck down and die.' (ESV)

text: Which prophet confronted David about his sin with Bathsheba and Uriah?
verseText: And the LORD sent Nathan to David... Nathan said to David, 'You are the man!' (ESV)

text: What was the immediate consequence of David's sin that Nathan announced?
options: The child born to Bathsheba would die
David would be struck with illness
verseText: Nevertheless, because by this deed you have utterly scorned the LORD, the child who is born to you shall die. (ESV)

text: What was the name of David and Bathsheba's second son, who succeeded David?
verseText: Then David comforted his wife, Bathsheba, and went in to her and lay with her, and she bore a son, and he called his name Solomon. And the LORD loved him. (ESV)

text: Which son of David raped his half-sister Tamar?
verseText: But he would not listen to her voice, and being stronger than she, he violated her and lay with her. (ESV)

text: Which son of David killed Amnon for raping Tamar?
verseText: Then Absalom commanded his servants, 'Mark when Amnon's heart is merry with wine... then kill him.'... And the servants of Absalom did to Amnon as Absalom had commanded. (ESV)

text: Which son of David rebelled against him and tried to take the throne?
verseText: But Absalom sent secret messengers throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, 'As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpet, then say, 'Absalom is king at Hebron!'... And a messenger came to David, saying, 'The hearts of the men of Israel have gone after Absalom.' (ESV)

text: Who was David's counselor who defected to Absalom?
verseText: And while Absalom was offering the sacrifices, he sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David's counselor, from his city Giloh. And the conspiracy grew strong, and the people with Absalom kept increasing... And it was told David, 'Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom.' (ESV)

text: Who pretended to defect to Absalom but remained loyal to David as a spy?
verseText: But if you return to the city and say to Absalom, 'I will be your servant, O king... Then you will defeat for me the counsel of Ahithophel.' (ESV)

text: How did Absalom die?
options: His hair got caught in a tree, and Joab killed him
Killed in battle by David's men
verseText: And Absalom happened to meet the servants of David. Absalom was riding on his mule, and the mule went under the thick branches of a great oak, and his head caught fast in the oak... Joab said, 'I will not waste time like this with you.' He took three javelins in his hand and thrust them into the heart of Absalom while he was still alive in the oak. (ESV)

text: Who was the commander of David's army?
verseText: Joab the son of Zeruiah was over the army... (ESV)

text: What did David do that displeased the Lord and led to a plague?
options: Numbered the fighting men of Israel and Judah
Made a treaty with the Philistines
verseText: Again the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, 'Go, number Israel and Judah.'... David's heart struck hin after he had numbered the people. And David said to the LORD, 'I have sinned greatly...' So the LORD sent a pestilence on Israel... (ESV)

text: Who was the prophet who gave David choices of punishment for his census?
verseText: When David arose in the morning, the word of the LORD came to the prophet Gad, David's seer, saying, 'Go and say to David, 'Thus says the LORD, Three things I offer you. Choose one of them, that I may do it to you.'' (ESV)

text: Where did David build an altar to stop the plague?
options: On the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite
verseText: And Gad came that day to David and said to him, 'Go up, raise an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.'... And David built there an altar to the LORD and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. So the LORD responded to the plea for the land, and the plague was averted from Israel. (ESV)

text: What later significant structure was built on the site of Araunah's threshing floor?
verseText: Then Solomon began to build the house of the LORD in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, where the LORD had appeared to David his father, at the place that David had appointed, on the threshing floor of Ornan [Araunah] the Jebusite. (2 Chron 3:1 ESV)

text: What was David's lament over Saul and Jonathan called?
verseText: And David lamented with this lamentation over Saul and Jonathan his son, and he said it should be taught to the people of Judah; behold, it is written in the Book of Jashar. He said: 'The Bow'. (ESV) [Text slightly adjusted for clarity, as 'The Bow' is the title given in some interpretations/translations]

text: Who was Joab's swift-footed brother killed by Abner?
verseText: And the three sons of Zeruiah were there, Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Now Asahel was as swift of foot as a wild gazelle... But he refused to turn aside. Therefore Abner struck him in the stomach with the butt of his spear, so that the spear came out at his back. And he fell there and died where he was. (ESV)

text: Why did Joab kill Abner?
options: To avenge the death of his brother Asahel
verseText: ...and there he struck him in the stomach, so that he died, for the blood of Asahel his brother. (3:27) So Joab and Abishai his brother killed Abner, because he had put their brother Asahel to death in the battle at Gibeon. (3:30) (ESV)

text: How did David react to the news of Abner's death?
options: He mourned publicly and cursed Joab
verseText: Afterward, when David heard of it, he said, 'I and my kingdom are forever guiltless before the LORD for the blood of Abner... May it fall upon the head of Joab...' Then David said to Joab and all the people who were with him, 'Tear your clothes and put on sackcloth and mourn before Abner.' And King David followed the bier. (ESV)

text: How did David react to the murderers of Ish-bosheth?
verseText: ...how much more, when wicked men have killed a righteous man in his own house on his bed, shall I not now require his blood at your hand and destroy you from the earth?' And David commanded his young men, and they killed them and cut off their hands and feet and hanged them beside the pool at Hebron. (ESV)

text: What strategic advantage did capturing Jerusalem offer David?
options: It was a neutral site between Judah and the northern tribes
It had the best water source
It was already heavily fortified by the Jebusites
It was prophesied as the capital
verseText: [Historical context: Jerusalem was on the border between Benjamin and Judah, not strongly associated with any single tribe, making it a suitable neutral capital for a united kingdom.] (ESV)

text: Whose house did the Ark of the Covenant stay in for three months after Uzzah's death?
verseText: And the ark of the LORD remained in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite three months, and the LORD blessed Obed-edom and all his household. (ESV)

text: What was the main promise God made to David in the Davidic Covenant (2 Samuel 7)?
options: God would establish David's dynasty and kingdom forever
David would conquer all surrounding nations
David would live a long life
verseText: And your house and your kingdom shall be made sure forever before me. Your throne shall be established forever. (ESV)

text: Who was Ziba?
options: A servant of Saul's house who managed Mephibosheth's estate
verseText: Now there was a servant of the house of Saul whose name was Ziba, and they called him to David... You and your sons and your servants shall till the land for him [Mephibosheth] and shall bring in the produce, that your master's grandson may have bread to eat. (ESV)

text: Which nation did David defeat after they humiliated his ambassadors by shaving their beards and cutting their garments?
verseText: So Hanun took David's servants and shaved off half the beard of each and cut off their garments in the middle, at their hips, and sent them away... And when Joab and the people who were with him drew near to battle against the Syrians, they fled before him. And when the Ammonites saw that the Syrians fled... they fled before Abishai and entered the city. (ESV)

text: What was Uriah the Hittite known for?
options: His loyalty and integrity, refusing comfort while the Ark and army were in the field
verseText: Uriah said to David, 'The ark and Israel and Judah dwell in booths, and my lord Joab and the servants of my lord are camping in the open field. Shall I then go to my house, to eat and to drink and to lie with my wife? As you live, and as your soul lives, I will not do this thing.' (ESV)

text: What parable did Nathan use to confront David?
options: A rich man taking a poor man's only lamb
A vineyard owner and wicked tenants
verseText: He said to him, 'There were two men in a certain city, the Tich and the poor. The rich man had very many flocks and herds, but the poor man hadnothing but one little ewe lamb... Now there came a traveler to the rich man, and he was unwilling to take one of his own flock... but he took the poor man's lamb...' (ESV)

text: Besides the death of the child, what long-term consequence did Nathan prophesy for David's sin?
options: 'The sword shall never depart from your house'
Loss of the kingdom to his son
verseText: Now therefore the sword shall never depart from your house, because you have despised me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife. (ESV)

text: Who advised Amnon on how to trick Tamar?
verseText: But Amnon had a friend, whose name was Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David's brother. And Jonadab vas a very crafty man... Jonadab said to him, 'Lie down on your bed and preten to be ill. And when your father comes to see you, say to him, 'Let my sister Tamar come and give me bread to eat...'' (ESV)

text: How long did Absalom live in exile in Geshur after killing Amnon?
verseText: So Absalom fled and went to Geshur, and was there three years. (ESV)

text: Who orchestrated Absalom's return from exile using a wise woman from Tekoa?
verseText: Now Joab the son of Zeruiah knew that the king's heart went out to Absalom. And Joab sent to Tekoa and brought from there a wise woman... Then the king said to Joab, 'Behold now, I grant this; go, bring back the young man Absalom.' (ESV)

text: How did Absalom steal the hearts of the men of Israel?
options: By intercepting people going to the king for judgment and showing them favor
verseText: And Absalom used to rise early and stand beside the way of the gate. And when any man had a dispute to come before the king for judgment, Absalom would call to him... 'See, your claims are good and right, but there is no man designated by the king to hear you.'... So Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel. (ESV)

text: Who cursed and threw stones at David as he fled Jerusalem?
verseText: When King David came to Bahurim, there came out a man of the family of the house of Saul, whose name was Shimei... And Shimei said as he cursed, 'Get out, get out, you man of blood, you worthless man! The LORD has avenged on you all the blood of the house of Saul...' (ESV)

text: What counsel did Ahithophel give Absalom that Hushai later defeated?
options: To pursue David immediately with 12,000 men
To consolidate his power in Jerusalem first
verseText: Moreover, Ahithophel said to Absalom, 'Let me choose twelve thousand men, and I will arise and pursue David tonight... And I will strike down only the king, and I will bring all the people back to you...' And the advice seemed right in the eyes of Absalom and all the elders of Israel. (ESV)

text: How did Ahithophel die?
options: He hanged himself when his counsel was rejected
verseText: When Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not followed, he saddled his donkey and went off home to his own city. He set his house in order and hanged himself, and he died and was buried in the tomb of his father. (ESV)

text: Who were the two priests who helped relay information to David through their sons?
verseText: Are not Zadok and Abiathar the priests with you there? So whatever you hear from the king's house, tell it to Zadok and Abiathar the priests. Behold, their two sons are with them there, Ahimaaz, Zadok's son, and Jonathan, Abiathar's son, and by them you shall send to me everything you hear. (ESV)

text: What command did David give his commanders regarding Absalom before the battle?
options: 'Deal gently for my sake with the young man Absalom'
verseText: And the king ordered Joab and Abishai and Ittai, 'Deal gently for my sake with the young man Absalom.' And all the people heard when the king gave orders to all the commanders about Absalom. (ESV)

text: Who brought David the news of Absalom's death?
options: Ahimaaz (son of Zadok) and a Cushite messenger
verseText: [Both Ahimaaz and the Cushite run to David. Ahimaaz arrives first but avoids giving the bad news directly; the Cushite confirms Absalom's death.] (ESV)

text: How did David react to the news of Absalom's death?
options: He wept bitterly, mourning 'O my son Absalom!'
verseText: And the king was deeply moved and went up to the chamber over the gate and wept. And as he went, he said, 'O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!' (ESV)

text: Who rebuked David for mourning Absalom excessively and neglecting the victorious army?
verseText: Then Joab came into the house to the king and said... 'You have today covered with shame the faces of all your servants... because you love those who hate you and ate those who love you... Now therefore arise, go out and speak kindly to your servants.' (ESV)

text: Who did David appoint as commander of the army in Joab's place after Absalom's rebellion?
verseText: And say to Amasa, 'Are you not my bone and my flesh? God do so to me and more also, if you are not commander of my army from now on in place of Joab.' (ESV)

text: What dispute arose between the men of Israel and the men of Judah regarding David's return?
options: Judah brought the king back without consulting Israel
Israel wanted Absalom's son to be king
Israel refused to accept David back
verseText: Then all the men of Israel came to the king and said to the king, 'Why have our brothers the men of Judah stolen you away...?' All the men of Judah answered the men of Israel... 'Because the king is our close relative...' The men of Israel answered the men of Judah... 'We have ten shares in the king...' (ESV)

text: Who led a rebellion against David shortly after Absalom's defeat, shouting 'We have no portion in David'?
verseText: Now there happened to be there a worthless man, whose name was Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjaminite. And he blew the trumpet and said, 'We have no portion in David, and we have no inheritance in the son of Jesse; every man to his tents, O Israel!' (ESV)

text: How did Amasa, the newly appointed commander, die?
verseText: And Joab said to Amasa, 'Is it well with you, my brother?' And Joab took Amasa by the beard with his right hand to kiss him. But Amasa did not observe the sword that was in Joab's hand. So Joab struck him with it in the stomach and spilled his entrails to the ground... and he died. (ESV)

text: How was Sheba's rebellion ended?
options: A wise woman from Abel Beth-maacah persuaded the city to behead Sheba and throw his head over the wall to Joab
David's army defeated Sheba's forces in battle
verseText: Then a wise woman called from the city... 'They seek Sheba the son of Bichri... Cut off his head and throw it over the wall to me.'... Then the woman went to all the people in her wisdom. And they cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bichri and threw it out to Joab. (ESV)

text: Why was there a three-year famine in Israel during David's reign?
options: Because Saul had broken a treaty and killed the Gibeonites
Because of David's sin with Bathsheba
verseText: Now there was a famine in the days of David for three years, year after year. And David sought the face of the LORD. And the LORD said, 'There is bloodguilt on Saul and on his house, because he put the Gibeonites to death.' (ESV)

text: What did the Gibeonites request as atonement for Saul's actions?
options: Seven of Saul's male descendants to be handed over for execution
verseText: They said to the king... 'Let seven of his sons be given to us, so that we may hang them before the LORD at Gibeah of Saul, the chosen of the LORD.' And the king said, 'I will give them.' (ESV)

text: Who protected the bodies of the executed sons of Saul from birds and beasts?
verseText: Then Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it for herself on the rock, from the beginning of harvest until rain fell upon them from the heavens. And she did not allow the birds of the air to come upon them by day, or the beasts of the field by night. (ESV)

text: Which giant, described as having six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, was killed by Jonathan, son of Shimei (David's brother)?
options: A descendant of the giants in Gath
verseText: And there was again war at Gath, where there was a man of great stature, who had six fingers on each hand, and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in number, and he also was descended from the giants. And when he taunted Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimei, David's brother, struck him down. (ESV)

text: Who rescued David when he was old and weary and nearly killed by the giant Ishbi-benob?
verseText: Ishbi-benob, one of the descendants of the giants... thought to kill David. But Abishai the son of Zeruiah came to his aid and attacked the Philistine and killed him. Then David's men swore to him, 'You shall no longer go out with us to battle, lest you quench the lamp of Israel.' (ESV)

text: 2 Samuel 22 is nearly identical to which Psalm?
verseText: And David spoke to the LORD the words of this song on the day when the LORD delivered him from the hand of all his enemies, and from the hand of Saul. (2 Sam 22:1) To the choirmaster. A Psalm of David, the servant of the LORD, who addressed the words of this song to the LORD on the day when the LORD rescued him from the hand of all his enemies, and from the hand of Saul. (Psalm 18 Title) (ESV)

text: Who were David's 'three mighty men' who broke through the Philistine lines to get him water from Bethlehem?
options: The text doesn't name them in this specific act, just 'the three mighty men'
verseText: And David said longingly, 'Oh, that someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem that is by the gate!' Then the three mighty men broke through the camp of the Philistines and drew water out of the well of Bethlehem that was by the gate and took it and brought it to David. (ESV)

text: What did David do with the water the three mighty men risked their lives to get?
options: Poured it out as an offering to the Lord
verseText: ...But he would not drink of it. He poured it out to the LORD and said, 'Far be it from me, O LORD, that I should do this. Shall I drink the blood of the men who went at the risk of their lives?' Therefore he would not drink it. (ESV)

text: Who was Benaiah son of Jehoiada known for killing?
options: A lion in a pit on a snowy day, and an imposing Egyptian
verseText: And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was a valiant man of Kabzeel... He struck down two ariels [lion-like heroes] of Moab. He also went down and struck down a lion in a pit on a day when snow had fallen. And he struck down an Egyptian, a handsome man... he snatched the spear out of the Egyptian's hand and killed him with his own spear. (ESV)

text: What were the three choices of punishment God offered David through Gad for the census?
options: Three years of famine, three months fleeing enemies, or three days of plague
Seven years famine, defeat in battle, locusts
verseText: So Gad came to David and told him, and said to him, 'Shall three years of famine come to you in your land? Or will you flee three months before your foes while they pursue you? Or shall there be three days' pestilence in your land?' (ESV) [Note: 1 Chron 21:12 has 'seven years']

text: Why did David insist on paying Araunah for the threshing floor and oxen?
options: He would not offer the Lord that which cost him nothing
Araunah refused to give it freely
verseText: But the king said to Araunah, 'No, but I will buy it from you for a price. I will not offer burnt offerings to the LORD my God that cost me nothing.' So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver. (ESV)

text: What is the significance of the Amalekite's conflicting account of Saul's death compared to 1 Samuel 31?
options: Suggests the Amalekite lied, possibly to gain favor from David
Shows a contradiction in the biblical text
Reveals a cover-up by Saul's armor bearer
verseText: [The Amalekite claims Saul asked him to deliver the killing blow after being wounded (2 Sam 1:9-10), whereas 1 Sam 31:4 states Saul fell on his own sword after his armor bearer refused.] (ESV)

text: Why was Hebron a significant location for David to be anointed king of Judah?
options: It was a major city in Judah, associated with Abraham, and the previous capital during the conquest
It was where Samuel first anointed him
It had the Tabernacle at that time
verseText: [Hebron's historical significance as an ancient patriarchal center and Caleb's inheritance made it a natural power base within Judah.] (ESV)

text: What does the battle at the Pool of Gibeon, where twelve men from each side fought and killed each other, signify?
options: The tragic and futile nature of the civil war between Judah (David) and Israel (Ish-bosheth)
A common method of settling disputes
verseText: And Abner said to Joab, 'Let the young men arise and compete before us.'... And each caught his opponent by the head and thrust his sword in his opponent's side, so they fell down together. Therefore that place was called Helkath-hazzurim [Field of Swords/Daggers]. (ESV)

text: What political motivation likely lay behind Abner's decision to defect to David?
options: His fallout with Ish-bosheth over Saul's concubine Rizpah, and recognizing David's growing strength
A genuine belief David was God's chosen
verseText: Now Saul had a concubine whose name was Rizpah... And Ish-bosheth said to Abner, 'Why have you gone in to my father's concubine?' Then Abner was very angry... and said... 'Today I will deal loyally with the house of Saul... and I will transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and set up the throne of David over Israel and over Judah...' (ESV)

text: Why did David demand the return of his wife Michal, Saul's daughter, as a condition for making a covenant with Abner?
options: To strengthen his claim to Saul's throne and legitimize his rule over all Israel
To spite her current husband, Paltiel
verseText: And he said, 'Good; I will make a covenant with you. But one thing I require of you: you shall not see my face unless you first bring Michal, Saul's daughter, when you come to see my face.' Then David sent messengers to Ish-bosheth... saying, 'Give me my wife Michal...' (ESV)

text: The Jebusites' taunt, 'You will not come in here, but the blind and the lame will ward you off,' likely refers to what?
options: Their overconfidence in the natural defenses and walls of Jerusalem
An actual garrison of blind and lame soldiers
verseText: And the king and his men went to Jerusalem against the Jebusites... who said to David, 'You will not come in here, but the blind and the lame will ward you off'—thinking, 'David cannot come in here.' (ESV)

text: How did David's forces likely capture the stronghold of Zion (Jerusalem)?
verseText: And David said on that day, 'Whoever strikes the Jebusites, let him get up the water shaft to attack 'the lame and the blind,' who are hated by David's soul.' (ESV) [1 Chron 11:6 credits Joab with leading the ascent]

text: What theological error likely led to Uzzah's death when touching the Ark?
options: Treating the Ark as a mere object and failing to follow specific transport instructions (e.g., carrying by poles, Levites only)
verseText: And they carried the ark of God on a new cart... (6:3) Uzzah put out his hand to the ark of God and took hold of it... And the anger of the LORD was kindled against Uzzah, and God struck him down there because of his error [or, irreverence]. (6:6-7) [Contrast with instructions for Levites to carry it on their shoulders using poles.] (ESV)

text: What is the significance of Michal, Saul's daughter, having no child 'to the day of her death'?
options: Seen as judgment for her contempt of David's worship, effectively ending Saul's line through her
A natural consequence of her age
David refused to have relations with her
verseText: And Michal the daughter of Saul had no child to the day of her death. (ESV)

text: The Davidic Covenant (2 Sam 7) is a foundational text for what theological concept?
options: Messianic expectation (the promise of an eternal king from David's line)
verseText: When your days are fulfilled and you lie down with your fathers, I will raise up your offspring after you... and I will establish his kingdom... I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever... And your house and your kingdom shall be made sure forever before me. (ESV)

text: What does David's treatment of Mephibosheth demonstrate?
options: His faithfulness to his covenant with Jonathan and his capacity for 'hesed' (covenant loyalty/lovingkindness)
Political maneuvering to neutralize a potential rival
verseText: And David said, 'Is there still anyone left of the house of Saul, that I may show him kindness [hesed] for Jonathan's sake?'... And David said to him, 'Do not fear, for I will show you kindness [hesed] for the sake of your father Jonathan...' (ESV)

text: What deeper failure is indicated by David remaining in Jerusalem 'at the time when kings go out to battle'?
options: Neglect of his kingly duties and responsibilities, creating an opportunity for temptation
verseText: In the spring of the year, the time when kings go out to battle, David sent Joab, and his servants with him, and all Israel... But David remained at Jerusalem. (ESV)

text: How does Uriah's integrity contrast sharply with David's actions in 2 Samuel 11?
options: Uriah's loyalty to God, Israel, and his comrades highlights David's disloyalty, abuse of power, and self-indulgence
verseText: [David tries to make Uriah go home to cover up the adultery, but Uriah refuses out of solidarity with those at war, contrasting with David's behavior.] (ESV)

text: What is the significance of David's response, 'I have sinned against the LORD,' after Nathan's confrontation?
options: A genuine, immediate confession and acceptance of responsibility without excuses
verseText: David said to Nathan, 'I have sinned against the LORD.' And Nathan said to David, 'The LORD also has put away your sin; you shall not die.' (ESV)

text: How does the rape of Tamar and murder of Amnon fulfill Nathan's prophecy?
options: They represent the 'sword' rising from David's own house as a consequence of his sin
They were direct punishments from God
They were caused by Absalom's ambition
verseText: 'Now therefore the sword shall never depart from your house... Behold, I will raise up evil against you out of your own house.' (12:10-11) [Chapter 13 details the rape and murder within David's family.] (ESV)

text: What does Absalom's physical appearance (especially his hair) symbolize in the narrative?
options: His pride, vanity, and perhaps his eventual downfall (as his hair leads to his capture)
verseText: Now in all Israel there was no one so much to be praised for his handsome appearance as Absalom... And when he cut the hair of his head (for at the end of every year he used to cut it; when it was heavy on him, he cut it), he weighed the hair of his head, two hundred shekels... (14:25-26) ...his head caught fast in the oak... (18:9) (ESV)

text: What is the significance of Absalom setting up a pillar for himself because he had no son?
options: Shows his desire for lasting fame and legacy, contrasting with God's promise of an eternal dynasty to David
A common practice for childless men
verseText: Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and set up for himself the pillar that is in the King's Valley, for he said, 'I have no son to keep my name in remembrance.' He called the pillar after his own name, and it is called Absalom's Monument to this day. (ESV)

text: How does Hushai's counsel defeat Ahithophel's?
options: By appealing to Absalom's vanity and caution, advising delay to gather a larger army, thus giving David time to escape
By proving Ahithophel was a traitor
verseText: Then Hushai said to Absalom, 'This time the counsel that Ahithophel has given is not good.'... 'But my counsel is that all Israel be gathered to you... and that you go to battle in person.'... And Absalom and all the men of Israel said, 'The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Ahithophel.' For the LORD had ordained to defeat the good counsel of Ahithophel, so that the LORD might bring harm upon Absalom. (ESV)

text: What is the significance of Ziba's accusation against Mephibosheth during David's flight?
options: It raises ambiguity about Mephibosheth's loyalty and highlights the chaos and betrayal during the rebellion
It proves Mephibosheth was a traitor
It shows Ziba's loyalty to David
It was immediately dismissed by David
verseText: [Ziba claims Mephibosheth stayed in Jerusalem hoping the kingdom would revert to Saul's house (16:3). Mephibosheth later claims Ziba slandered him and prevented him from joining David (19:26-27). David's final decision (19:29) seems to split the difference, leaving the truth uncertain.] (ESV)

text: David's lament over Absalom reveals what tension in his character?
options: The conflict between his role as king (needing victory) and his love as a father
His preference for Absalom over his loyal men
verseText: [David's overwhelming grief for his rebellious son almost undermines the victory his army won for him, requiring Joab's harsh rebuke.] (ESV)

text: Why might Joab have disregarded David's command to deal gently with Absalom?
options: Belief that Absalom's death was necessary for the kingdom's stability and to end the rebellion decisively
verseText: [Joab recognizes the political necessity of eliminating the rebel leader, prioritizing the kingdom's security over David's personal feelings.] (ESV)

text: What does the rivalry between the men of Judah and the men of Israel after Absalom's death foreshadow?
options: The eventual split of the kingdom after Solomon's reign
The rise of a new leader
verseText: [The dispute over who had more right to the king and Sheba's subsequent rebellion highlight the underlying tribal tensions that would later divide Israel and Judah.] (ESV)

text: What is the theological significance of the Gibeonite massacre issue resurfacing years later?
options: Demonstrates that unresolved national sin (breaking covenant) can have long-term consequences requiring atonement
Suggests David used it as a pretext to eliminate Saul's line
verseText: And the LORD said, 'There is bloodguilt on Saul and on his house, because he put the Gibeonites to death.' So the king called the Gibeonites... (Now the Gibeonites were not of the people of Israel but of the remnant of the Amorites; although the people of Israel had sworn to spare them, Saul had sought to strike them down in his zeal...) (ESV)

text: What does Rizpah's vigil over her sons' bodies symbolize?
options: Profound maternal grief, devotion, and a silent protest against the injustice or harshness of the situation
verseText: [Her actions shamed David into giving the bones of Saul and his descendants a proper burial, highlighting her loyalty and the pathos of the event.] (ESV)

text: The list of David's mighty men and their exploits (2 Sam 23) serves what purpose in the narrative?
options: To honor David's loyal followers, showcase the strength of his kingdom, and attribute success ultimately to God
verseText: [The list highlights the human element in establishing David's kingdom, complementing the divine promises and actions described elsewhere.] (ESV)

text: What is the theological problem presented by 2 Samuel 24:1 stating 'the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he incited David'?
options: It raises questions about divine sovereignty and human responsibility (cf. 1 Chron 21:1 attributes the inciting to Satan)
It suggests David was not responsible
It implies Israel deserved the plague
verseText: Again the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, 'Go, number Israel and Judah.' (ESV) [The parallel passage in 1 Chron 21:1 says 'Satan stood up against Israel and incited David'. This highlights complex theological perspectives on God's sovereignty, permission, and secondary causes.]

text: Why might numbering the people have been considered a sin?
options: It potentially reflected pride, reliance on military strength instead of God, or violated a prohibition against census-taking without specific divine command or atonement (Ex 30:12)
verseText: But Joab said to the king, 'May the LORD your God add to the people a hundred times as many... but why does my lord the king delight in this thing?' (24:3) David's heart struck him after he had numbered the people. And David said to the LORD, 'I have sinned greatly...' (24:10) [Exodus 30:12 links census-taking with atonement money to avoid plague.] (ESV)

text: What is the significance of David choosing the plague ('let us fall into the hand of the LORD, for his mercy is great')?
options: Shows David's ultimate trust in God's mercy over human cruelty or the slow agony of famine
He believed it would be the shortest punishment
He wanted to share the suffering with his people
He thought God wouldn't go through with it
verseText: Then David said to Gad, 'I am in great distress. Let us fall into the hand of the LORD, for his mercy is great; but let me not fall into the hand of man.' (ESV)

text: The purchase of Araunah's threshing floor, the site of the future Temple, signifies what?
options: Atonement, reconciliation with God at a place chosen by Him, and the foundation for future worship
The end of the Jebusite presence
verseText: And David built there an altar to the LORD... So the LORD responded to the plea for the land, and the plague was averted from Israel. [This location becomes the site where Solomon builds the Temple, linking atonement and worship.] (ESV)

text: How does the book of 2 Samuel portray the complexities of leadership, faith, and human failure?
options: By showing David as both a man after God's own heart and a deeply flawed individual whose sins had consequences, yet also highlighting God's grace and covenant faithfulness
By focusing only on military victories
By condemning all forms of monarchy
verseText: [The narrative arc covers David's triumphs (uniting Israel, establishing Jerusalem, covenant with God) and tragedies (sin with Bathsheba, family strife, rebellion, plague), offering a realistic portrait of leadership under God.] (ESV)
